newsitem.title: USA: US 30-, 15-yr mortgage interest rates fall in week.
newsitem.headline: US 30-, 15-yr mortgage interest rates fall in week.

text.p: Average interest rates on U.S. 30- and 15-year fixed-rate mortgages fell in the week ending November 1 from the previous week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp said on Thursday.
Freddie Mac said 30-year mortgages averaged 7.78 percent, down eight basis points from 7.86 percent last week.
Fifteen-year loans fell to an average 7.30 percent from 7.37 percent the previous week.
But adjustable rate mortgages inched upward to an average 5.60 percent from 5.57 percent in the week, it said.
A year ago, the 30-year rate averaged 7.44 percent, the 15-year 6.97 percent and the ARM 5.67 percent.
Frank Nothaft, deputy chief economist for Freddie Mac, said recent reports on declines in U.S. home sales were "consistent with the slowdown of the economy."

"Consequently, news of the slower growth encouraged long-term interest rates to move downward this week," Nothaft said. Last Friday, the National Association of Realtors reported a 2.9 percent decrease in sales of U.S. September existing homes to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.02 million units.
On Wednesday, the Commerce Department said U.S. new home sales fell 0.5 percent last month to an annual rate of 816,000 units.
On Friday the Labor Department will issue U.S. October employment data.

Freddie Mac said lenders charged an average 1.8 percent in fees and points on 30-year loans and 1.5 percent on the ARM, both unchanged from last week. They charged 1.7 percent on 15-year mortgages, down from 1.8 percent last week.
